titlestmt.title: America a Prophecy Copy B: electronic edition

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 310KB; 36 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 70.9KB to 1800KB
filedesc.publicationstmt:
Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and Archives
January 2013
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of America a Prophecy Copies B and I. Ten of the fourteen extant copies of America were printed in 1793, the date on its title plate. Copy I, now in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, is from this printing. The eighteen plates of Copy I, like those of the other 1793 copies but unlike those of the later copies, were printed on two sides of the leaves, except for the frontispiece and title page (plates 1 and 2), and left uncolored. The plates were printed in greenish-black ink; five lines at the end of the text on plate 4 were masked and did not print, and plate 13 is in its first state. Copy B was printed in 1795 with Copy A in the same brownish black ink on one side of the paper, with plate 13 in its second state. Unlike Copy A, however, it is uncolored except for gray wash on the title plate. Now in the Morgan Library and Museum, Copy B has a very curious history. Its plates 4 and 9, which were long assumed to be original, are in fact lithographic facsimiles from the mid 1870s produced to complete the copy. For a full technical description and history of this copy, see Joseph Viscomi, “Two Fake Blakes Revisited; One Dew-Smith Revealed.” Blake in Our Time: Essays in Honour of G. E. Bentley, Jr. Ed. Karen Mulhallen. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2010. 35-78. Copies B and I join six other copies in the Archive, Copies E and F (1793), A (1795), M (c. 1807), and O (1821), which altogether represent the full printing history of this illuminated book.
America a Prophecy was the first of Blake's "Continental Prophecies," followed by Europe a Prophecy in 1794, executed in the same style and size but usually colored, and, in 1795, "Africa" and "Asia," two sections making up The Song of Los . Fine and important examples of all three works are in the Archive. Like all the illuminated books in the Archive, the text and images of America Copies B and I are fully searchable and are supported by the Archive's Compare feature. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to Copies B and I and to all the America texts previously published.
With the publication of these two copies, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 85 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, color printed drawings, tempera paintings, and water color drawings.
Due to recent security concerns related to Java browser plugins, the Archive has disabled its Java-based ImageSizer and Virtual Lightbox applications. Users can still view 100 and 300 dpi JPEG images as well as complete transcriptions for all works in the Archive including America Copies B and I. Text searching is also still available for all works in the Archive, and image searching remains available for all works except those in preview mode. In the coming months the Archive will implement redesigned pages that restore the features of ImageSizer and the Virtual Lightbox without the use of Java.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.numberobj:
18
In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed from a small, separate copperplate, plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, and O, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand. Plate 11 is in the second of two states, with additional white line work in the lower left margin and just above the bottom edge of the plate. The first state is found only in Copy L. Plate 13 is in the second state, with one tail on the snake, lower left. Plates 4 and 9 in this copy are lithographic reproductions, perhaps based on Copy F. For a full explanation, see Joseph Viscomi, "Two Fake Blakes Revisited; One Dew-Smith Revealed," Blake in Our Time: Essays in Honour of G. E. Bentley, Jr , ed. Karen Mulhallen (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2010) 35-78.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 23.8 x 17.4 cm. and 23.1 x 16.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: Relief etching, with extensive white-line etching on Objects 1, 8, 10, 11, and 15, and gray wash on Object 2 (the title page). Most other objects bear at least touches of white-line etching/engraving. Objects 4 and 9 are lithographic reproductions; see the note following Number of Objects, above. There are inscriptions and sketches, not by Blake, on the versos of Objects 1 (bound as a recto because Object 1, the frontispiece, faces Object 2, the title page), 2, and 17. The small drawing (a branch or vine with many thin leaves) on the back of Object 1 appears under an inscription, "Mary Taylor London." This drawing is in the same brown ink, and appears to have been executed with the same pen, as the inscription. This drawing is very probably by Taylor. The ink drawing of a winged human figure, probably an angel, on the verso of Object 2 might be by Taylor, or by C. H. Tatham, the first owner of the volume, or by Albert George Dew-Smith, who owned the volume from c. 1874 to 1878 (see the note on Provenance, below). The pencil sketches on the verso of Object 17 may be by Tatham or Dew-Smith. They include two heads in profile, a head and torso in profile, possibly a duck, and a landscape including a walking figure, a tree, and a building or gravestone with a cross above. For these verso inscriptions and sketches, see Related Works in the Archive. For the pen and ink sketch added to Object 5, see the Editors' Notes on Object 5.
objinfo.watermark: 1794 / J Whatman The watermark appears on the leaves bearing Objects 1, 5, 8, 11, and 18.
objinfo.pennednumbers: none Pencil numbers, top right and bottom left, are not by Blake.
objinfo.binding: citron morocco by F. Bedford Object 1, the frontispiece, is bound facing Object 2, the title page.
objinfo.stabholes: Stabbed once through three holes, 6.5 and 7.7 cm. apart. Stabbed again through three holes, 10.7 aand 12.9 cm. apart.

desc.objtitle:
America a Prophecy,
Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

objnote.p: There are two inscriptions and a drawing, not by Blake, on the verso of Object 1; see Related Works in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design embodies the destructiveness of warfare. In the middle distance is a stone wall with, on the right, the fragments of a top carved with classical motifs. A great gap appears to the left, and in this gap sits a giant winged figure. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution. To the right is a family group, all nude. A woman, very probably a mother, sits on a fragment of the stone wall, legs crossed. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His (right?) knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. This figure's legs are crossed at the ankles. We see this figure from behind. On the ground below the woman is the haft of a broken sword, and further to the left is a dismounted cannon. The sky is dominated by dark clouds, perhaps of smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant winged male sits or squats in a gap in a partly-destroyed wall. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution.

Three nude figures, probably a mother and two children, huddle together. The woman sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His (right?) knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. We see this figure from behind.

A nude female, probably the mother of the two children with her, sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. Her legs are crossed and her left(?) hand rests on her right knee. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male.
The woman holds in her lap a nude child, probably male. He faces forward, but may be looking up at the woman. We see only his face, right upper arm, and prominent (right?) knee.

A nude child of uncertain gender huddles with the woman. We see this figure from behind; his or her head is hidden by the woman's left arm. The figure's legs are crossed at the ankles; the buttocks are prominent.
The wrists of the giant winged figure are shackled and chained.

The middle distance of the design is dominated by a stone wall, partly ruined. The top is decorated with classical motifs, perhaps including the egg and dart motif and palmettes. The family group, lower right, sits on a fragment of the decorated top of the wall.
The piece of broken wall on which the giant winged figure sits looks like a plinth--and hence he looks like a statue.
The sky is dominated by clouds, perhaps of smoke.
The haft of a broken sword lies on the ground below the family group.
A dismounted cannon lies on the ground.

objnote.p: There are an inscription and a pen and ink drawing of a winged human figure, probably an angel, on the verso of Object 2. These are not by Blake; see Related Works in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lowest part of the design is formed of male corpses stacked like cord wood. We see, on the first level of the stack, the tops of the heads and horizontally-extended arms of two rigid bodies lying prone. The next layer is a single rigid body, lying supine, with his legs extended to the right and his arms at his side. He faces up. Above him is a gowned woman with long hair, lying on top of him with her left leg drawn up and her right leg extended. She embraces the man around the neck with her left arm. Her face, seen in profile, touches the dead or dying man's face below her; she may be kissing him, trying to resuscitate him, or simply mourning over him. Her mouth is partly open. The dark sky above these figures contains a few diagonal white lines that may indicate rain or sleet descending from the clouds above. These large clouds bear the title, as though inscribed upon them, and six figures. On the left, a gowned woman with long hair sits with right leg extended before her and her left leg bent back behind her. She faces and hunches over to the left, apparently holding a book or tablet also being looked at or read by a gowned child, probably male, with curly hair. He stands before the woman and faces right, but is probably looking down at the book or tablet. At least his right arm is extended horizontally and may rest on the book or tablet. Behind the woman is another figure, perhaps nude and female, sitting with legs extended and her back leaning against the back of the woman. Although the scale of the figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young girl. Another group of three figures is on the right. An old, bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears a heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. His posture is contracted, in contrast to the figure to the right--a nude female hovering in the air. We see her from behind; her posture is gracefully twisted. Her left arm is raised horizontally, her right arm at 135 degrees. The index finger on her right hand points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up. Her hair is in a bun. Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and facing to the right although his body is turned to the left and leans against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and he points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm is bent and supported against the old man's back. Although these two nude figures are much smaller than the old man, they are probably not children but energetic representations of spiritual states unperceived, or ignored, by the old man. The two large figures with books or tablets have sometimes been identified as a sibyl and a prophet. Alternatively, the male may be a priest.

component.illusobjdesc: The lowest part of the design is formed of male corpses stacked like cord wood. We see, on the first level of the stack, the tops of the heads and horizontally-extended arms of two rigid bodies lying prone.

A nude male lies supine on top of the prone corpses. His legs extend to the right and his one visible arm is at his side. He faces up. He is rigid and is probably dead or dying. His right foot is prominent and he may be holding something in his right hand.

Above the supine male is a gowned woman with long hair, lying on top of him with her left leg drawn up and her right leg extended. She embraces the man around the neck with her left arm. Her face, seen in profile, touches the dead or dying man's face below her; she may be kissing him, trying to resuscitate him, or simply mourning over him. Her mouth is partly open.

Left of the word "a" in the title inscription (line 2), a gowned woman with long hair sits with right leg extended before her and left leg bent back behind her. She faces and hunches over to the left, apparently holding, with her extended left arm and hand, a book or tablet which she may be reading. She has sometimes been identified as a sibyl.
The seated woman holds and appears to read a book or tablet in her lap.

A gowned child with curly hair, probably male, stands before the seated woman. He faces right and apparently looks at and perhaps reads the tablet or book held by the woman. His right arm is raised horizontally and perhaps points to a passage in the book or tablet.

Behind the large seated woman is another figure, perhaps nude and female, sitting with legs extended and her back leaning against the back of the woman. Although the scale of the figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young girl. She turns her head toward us. Her right arm dangles at her side, and she may be pointing downward.

Right of the word "a" in the title inscription (line 2), an old, bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears a heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. He may be a prophet or priest.
The seated old man holds and appears to read a book or tablet in his lap.

A nude female hovers in the air right of the old man. We see her from behind; her body is gracefully twisted, with her head facing to the left. Her left arm is raised horizontally, her right at 135 degrees. The index finger on her right hand points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up. Her hair is in a bun.

Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and facing to the right although his body is turned to the left and leans against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and he points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm is bent and supported against the old man's back, against which he leans. A lock of his (long?) hair drifts to the left.

The dark and stormy sky above the woman lying on the corpses contains cloud outlines and diagonal white lines perhaps representing rain or sleet. The angle of the rain or sleet indicates a wind blowing from left to right.
The upper two-thirds of the plate contains cloud outlines that indicate that both the title words and associated figures float on these clouds or hover before them.

objnote.p: On the verso of Object 2 there is a pen and ink drawing of a winged human figure (probably an angel), a pin-prick pattern in the form of an "S," and an inscription, none of them by Blake. The drawing may have been executed by Mary Taylor (see the inscription lower left on the verso of Object 1), or by C. H. Tatham, the first owner of the volume, or by Albert George Dew-Smith, who owned the volume from c. 1874 to 1878 (see the note on Provenance on the Copy Information page). The same hand, probably using the same ink, probably executed the drawing on Object 5 (see the Editors' Notes on Object 5).

objnote.p: In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed from a small, separate copperplate, plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, and O, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it appears as though the plate is treated as a single design extending across the top one third, down the left margin, and across the lower margin. A large tree, perhaps an oak, with arching branches dominates the top left of the design. The vegetation right and left of the large trunk may be separate bushes. Below and to the right of its trunk is a large stone or earthen bank (with a few tufts of grass) to which is shackled a nude, youthful male by both hands and feet. His arms are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained. To the right are a nude male and female, both standing. The female, with legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left--toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother. Further to the right, the male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but he turns his head to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father. Alternatively, the couple has been identified as Adam and Eve, or as the "Dark virgin" and Urthona (another name for Los) mentioned on this plate (lines 12, 2). The roots of the tree descend through the left margin, perhaps taking on anthropomorphic shapes. At the end of the roots, in the far lower left corner of the plate, sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is curly or flame-like. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out. A reticulated worm, with six loops, fills the lower margin. The loops suggest (although they do not quite form) a spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, youthful male is shackled and chained to a stone or earthen bank by both hands and feet. His arms and fingers are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained.
Shackles and a link or two of chains appear on the wrists and ankles of the youth.

A nude female, with long hair and legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left--toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother, but she has also been identified as the "Dark virgin" named on the plate (line 11).

A nude male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but his head is turned to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father, but he has also been identified as Urthona (another name for Los, mentioned on this plate in lines 1 and 16) and as Adam.

In the far lower left corner of the plate sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is spiky or flame-like. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out.
A large, reticulated worm fills the lower margin. Its six loops suggest, but do not quite form, a spiral.

A large tree, perhaps an oak, dominates the top left quarter of the plate. Its branches arch over to the right; a few leaves appear on the descending branches far right. Its roots descend down the left margin of the plate; some have anthropomorphic shapes, particularly left of lines 10-15 of the text.
The vegetation right and left of the large trunk of the tree may be separate, leafy plants.
Tufts of grass appear below the right leg of the shackled figure. To the left, below his right arm, are slight indications of grass or moss.
Narrow shadows appear beneath of the feet of the standing man and woman.
The youth sits on a small mound.
The youthful male is shackled to a large stone or earthen bank.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 15-16, and some may bear flowers. Vines left of lines 3-4 may bear flowers. Vines right of lines 2 and 6 form loops. The vine left of lines 19- 20 forms a small spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 15-16, and some may bear flowers. Vines right of lines 1 and 6 form loops. The vine left of lines 19-20 forms a small spiral.

l.note: In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed from a small, separate copperplate, plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, and O, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand.

lg.l: The shadowy daughter of Urthona stood before red Orc,
When fourteen suns had faintly journey'd o'er his dark abode;
His food she brought in iron baskets, his drink in cups of iron;
Crown'd with a helmet & dark hair the nameless female stood;
A quiver with its burning stores, a bow like that of night,
When pestilence is shot from heaven; no other arms she need:
Invulnerable tho' naked, save where clouds roll round her loins,
Their awful folds in the dark air; silent she stood as night;
For never from her iron tongue could voice or sound arise;
But dumb till that dread day when Orc assay'd his fierce embrace.
Dark virgin; said the hairy youth. thy father stern abhorr'd;
Rivets my tenfold chains while still on high my spirit soars;
Sometimes an eagle screaming in the sky, sometimes a lion,
Stalking upon the mountains, & sometimes a whale I lash
The raging fathomless abyss, anon a serpent folding
Around the pillars of Urthona, and round thy dark limbs,
On the Canadian wilds I fold, feeble my spirit folds.
For chaind beneath I rend these caverns; when thou bringest food
I howl my joy: and my red eyes seek to behold thy face
In vain! these clouds roll to & fro, & hide thee from my sight.

objnote.p:
This object is a lithographic reproduction not by Blake; see Copy Information for details. Five lines of verse etched on the copperplate following line 17 were masked during printing in Copies B-F, H-M, R, and a. These lines were erased after printing in Copy G (Bentley page 94). These lines, printed in Copies A, N-Q, read:
The stern Bard ceas'd, asham'd of his own song; enrag'd he swung
His harp aloft sounding, then dash'd its shining frame against
A ruin'd pillar in glittring fragments; silent he turn'd away
And wander'd down the vales of Kent in sick & drear la-
mentings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing a good deal of text, the plate is treated almost as a full-page design, with pictorial motifs filling the lower third of the plate and continuing up the left margin. In the lower margin, a muscular nude youth with curly, flame- like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. His right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc. To the left are a good many roots, as though we could see below the surface of the earth. Above these roots is a large plant growing up the left margin. It bears two large leaves and a long branch that terminates in a grain tassel. To the left of this plant is a vine that forms a long, vertical spiral. There are a few small plants and tufts of grass right of the nude male and left and right of the large plant.

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude youth with curly, flame-like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. His right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc.
The figure rises from a small depression (suggestive of a grave?) in a mound of earth or side of a cliff. Behind him is part of the mound or a small hill.
The surface of the earth is indicated by a few small plants with leaves and perhaps grass, far right. A few small plants or tuffs of grass grow left and right of the main plant on the left.

A large plant dominates the left margin of the plate. We see its roots beneath the surface of the earth, two large leaves, and a long branch growing up the left margin that terminates in a grain tassel. A spiral vine also grows up the left margin, with one loop around the main plant.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text and the margins are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves; large vines left of lines 2-5 and 7-15 include loops. On top of the second of these vines, just above the first word in line 7, is a small seated figure, bending forward and facing to the right with at least one leg extended to the right and one arm possibly reaching toward the foot. Another small figure seems to be hovering above "have" in the same line of text, facing left, one arm raised horizontally and one raised vertically, and legs spread apart. This figure may be holding the vine to the left. A vine growing from the first letter of the last word in line 7 ("go") includes two loops suggestive of a spiral. A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 15; smaller birds fly above "will" (line 7) and "me" (line 9). The last word of the final line grows into a vine with two leaves; most of this vine turns to the left and underlines the last line of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A small figure sits on the vine above the first word of line 7 of the text. He or she faces to the right, bending forward with at least one leg extended and one arm possibly reaching toward the foot.
A small figure hovers above "have" in line 7 of the text. He or she faces left, one arm raised horizontally and one vertically, and legs spread apart. The figure may be holding the vine to the left.

The spaces between lines and in the margins are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves; large vines left of lines 2-5 and 7-15 include loops. A vine growing from the first letter of the last word in line 7 ("go") includes two loops suggestive of a spiral.
A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 15. Smaller birds fly above "will" (line 7) and "me" (line 9).
The last word of the final line of text grows into a vine with two leaves; most of this vine turns to the left and underlines the last line of text.

lg.l: Silent as despairing love, and strong as jealousy,
The hairy shoulders rend the links, free are the wrists of fire;
Round the terrific loins he siez'd the panting struggling womb;
It joy'd: she put aside her clouds & smiled her first-born smile;
As when a black cloud shews its light'nings to the silent deep,
Soon as she saw the terrible boy then burst the virgin cry.
I know thee, I have found thee, & I will not let thee go;
Thou art the image of God who dwells in darkness of Africa:
And thou art fall'n to give me life in regions of dark death.
On my American plains I feel the struggling afflictions
Endur'd by roots that writhe their arms into the nether deep:
I see a serpent in Canada, who courts me to his love;
In Mexico an Eagle, and a Lion in Peru;
I see a Whale in the South-sea, drinking my soul away.
O what limb rending pains I feel, thy fire & my frost
Mingle in howling pains, in furrows by thy lightnings rent;
This is eternal death; and this the torment long foretold.

l.note:
Five lines of verse etched on the copperplate following line 17 were masked during printing in Copies B-F, H-M, R, and a. These lines were erased after printing in Copy G (Bentley page 94). These lines, printed in Copies A, N-Q, read:
The stern Bard ceas'd, asham'd of his own song; enrag'd he swung
His harp aloft sounding, then dash'd its shining frame against
A ruin'd pillar in glittring fragments; silent he turn'd away
And wander'd down the vales of Kent in sick & drear la-
mentings.

objnote.p: Above the final letter of "PROPHECY" (line 2 of the text) is the outline, in pen and ink, of a butterfly or moth with antennae clearly indicated. This additional motif was not drawn by Blake; it may have been drawn by C. H. Tatham, the first owner of the volume, or by Mary Taylor, another early owner, or by Albert George Dew-Smith, who owned the volume from c. 1874 to 1878. The same hand, probably using the same ink, probably drew the winged figure on the verso of Object 2; see Related Works in the Archive. See also the notes on Medium and on Provenance on the Copy Information page.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The area above the text bearing the heading ("A / PROPHECY") (lines 1-2) apparently represents the sky. Six birds fly on extended wings; three of these seem to be soaring upwards. Upper left, a nude, muscular male also seems to be ascending. He has apparently broken free of the chains that still dangle from his wrists. His right arm is at his side; his left arm is bent back over his left shoulder. His left leg is bent behind him; we see only the left ankle and foot. His hair may be curly. He faces forward with head tilted up. This may be another representation of Orc or, more generally, humanity freed from its chains by revolution. The words of the heading are integrated into vegetative design motifs, including several vines with leaves, spiraling vines growing from the first and last letters of "PROPHECY" (line 2), and grain stems and tassels growing from the first word of the heading ("A") (line 1).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, muscular male ascends through the sky. He has apparently broken free of the chains that still dangle from his wrists. His right arm is at his side; his left arm is bent back over his left shoulder. His left leg is bent behind him; we see only the left ankle and foot. His hair may be curly. He faces forward with head tilted up. This may be another representation of Orc or, more generally, humanity freed from its chains by revolution.
Chains dangle from the wrists of the ascending figure.

A bird flies on extended wings just left of the first letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 2). Another bird flies above the upper loop of the first letter of the first word ("The") of the body of the text (line 3).

Four birds fly on extended wings: a rising bird above the "C" of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 2), another rising bird below this same letter, a rising bird right of the descender of the final letter of "PROPHECY," and, just above this bird, a smaller bird flying horizontally. All but the last of these birds have forked tails. To the right of the first of these birds is the outline, in pen and ink, of a butterfly or moth with antennae clearly indicated. This additional motif was not drawn by Blake; it may have been executed by Mary Taylor, an early owner of this copy. See the notes on Medium and Provenance on the Copy Information page.

The first diagonal of "A" in the heading (line 1) grows at its lower end into a vine terminated by either leaves or a flower with a prominent stamen. Descending from the middle of the letter is an intertwined vine with small flowers. The second diagonal of "A" in the heading grows at its lower end into arching grain stems with tassels.
The first letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 2) grows into a spiral vine, upper left. Another vine, with ivy-like leaves and perhaps flowers, is intertwined with the letter.
The third letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 2) grows into a spiral vine. The next letter grows, lower left, into a vine with one loop.
The top of "H" in "PROPHECY" (line 2) grows into a vine with one loop. The vine terminates either in some leaves or a flower with a prominent stamen.
The descender of the last letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 2) grows into a vine running horizontally below the word. The vine has three loops, suggesting a spiral.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Between lines 7 and 8 of the text, a hovering nude male, perhaps an apocalyptic angel of the last trump, holds with both hands and blows into a large trumpet. We see him from behind; his hair is long and streams to the left, as though blown by a wind. Issuing from the mouth of the trumpet is a great blast of fire that turns upward in the left margin of the plate. Below, and evidently part of the same design, are further flames, including a line of fire between lines 14 and 16 of the text. A few curved lines left of lines 11-12 of the text suggest smoke. In the lower left corner of the plate is a nude family group fleeing from the fires above and behind them. The male (father?) is in the middle; he holds the hand of a young boy on the left. He strides forward with his left leg and looks back at the flames. His hair may be curly. The woman (mother?) strides forward with her right leg, also turns back to the flames, and raises her left arm over her head. The fingers of her left hand are spread apart. The boy on the left strides forward with his left leg, also seems to be looking back, and raises his right arm over his head. All three figures stride over a small mound of earth or hill.

component.illusobjdesc: Between lines 7 and 8 of the text, a hovering male figure, perhaps an apocalyptic angel of the last trump, holds with both hands and blows into a large trumpet. He is nude. We see him from behind; his hair is long and streams to the left, as though blown by a wind. Issuing from the mouth of the trumpet is a great blast of fire that turns upward in the left margin of the plate.

In the lower left corner of the plate is a nude family group fleeing from the fires above and behind them. The male (father?) is in the middle; he holds the hand of a young boy on the left. He strides forward with his left leg and looks back at the flames. His hair may be curly. The woman (mother?) strides forward with her right leg, also turns back to the flames, and raises her left arm over her head. The fingers of her left hand are spread apart. The boy on the left strides forward with his left leg, also seems to be looking back, and raises his right arm over his head. All three figures stride over a small mound of earth or hill.

In the center of the family group, a nude male, perhaps a father, strides forward with his left leg. He looks back at the flames behind him from which he is fleeing; his hair is curly. He holds the hand of the young boy on the left.

On the left of the family group is a nude male child. He strides forward with his left leg, fleeing the flames above and behind him. His head is turned back or to the left; his right arm is raised over his head. He holds the hand of the central male figure with his left hand.

On the right of the family group is a nude woman, perhaps the mother. She strides forward with her right leg, fleeing the flames above and behind her. Her head is turned back and to the left; her left arm is raised vertically, with the fingers of her left hand spread apart. Her hair may be drawn into a bun.

Flames issue from the trumpet blown by the figure between lines 7 and 8 of the text. Similar tongues of fire extend toward the family group in the lower left corner of the plate and between lines 14 and 16 of the text. A few curved lines left of lines 11-12 of the text suggest smoke.
The family group in the lower left corner of the plate runs over a mound of earth or low hill. Shadows extend from their feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lower end of the first letter ("T") in line 3 terminates in a leaf or flower. A twisting line extends from the first letter of the second word ("Guardian") in line 3. This may represent a vine. Several letters have vine-like extensions, some with loops (e.g., left of lines 4 and 7).

component.illusobjdesc: The lower end of the first letter ("T") in line 3 terminates in a leaf or flower. A twisting line extends from the first letter of the second word ("Guardian") in line 3. This may represent a vine. Several letters have vine-like extensions, some with loops (e.g., left of lines 4 and 7).

lg.l: The Guardian Prince of Albion burns in his nightly tent,
Sullen fires across the Atlantic glow to America's shore:
Piercing the souls of warlike men, who rise in silent night,
Washington, Franklin, Paine & Warren, Gates, Hancock & Green;
Meet on the coast glowing with blood from Albions fiery Prince.
Washington spoke; Friends of America look over the Atlantic sea;
A bended bow is lifted in heaven, & a heavy iron chain
Descends link by link from Albions cliffs across the sea to bind
Brothers & sons of America, till our faces pale and yellow;
Heads deprest, voices weak, eyes downcast, hands work-bruis'd,
Feet bleeding on the sultry sands, and the furrows of the whip
Descend to generations that in future times forget.------
sea.
The strong voice ceas'd; for a terrible blast swept over the heaving
The eastern cloud rent; on his cliffs stood Albions wrathful Prince
A dragon form clashing his scales at midnight he arose,
And flam'd red meteors round the land of Albion beneath
His voice, his locks, his awful shoulders, and his glowing eyes,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it would appear that the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. At top right, just below line 1, is a winged dragon of a type traditionally called a wyvern. The creature is apparently flying through the air. It faces to the left, with a coiled or spiral tail with one loop on the right. Its skin looks scaly and its face is somewhat dog-like, with a partly opened mouth and large teeth. The top of its head bears a crest. Its front paws look almost like human hands. Below and to the left of its left paw is a jagged line, perhaps representing a bolt of lightning. Further to the left, and descending into the left margin, is an old man. His gown forms a long, snake-like tail behind him, rather like the wyvern's tail. He has a long beard and long hair. His right arm is at his side, but we can see that, with his right hand, he grasps a large book or tablet. His left arm reaches downward and he holds in his left hand a scepter or spear with a fleur-de-lis point. This figure may be Albion's Angel or Urizen (twice referred to in the text) with his book of laws. Below this descending figure is another jagged line, perhaps representing lightning, and several cloud outlines extending to the right margin above the last two lines of text. Below these billowing clouds, in the plate's lower margin, is a landscape that includes three figures, probably a family group of father, mother, and child. Lower left is the trunk of a large tree, fallen on the ground to the left. On the right, behind the figure group, is another fallen tree with a branch extending upward to the right margin. The male is the left-most figure in the group, lower right. He is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent forward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture, and his crude facial features, express despair or terror. To the right is a crouching female. She may be gowned or nude. Her left knee and foot are prominent. She turns her head to the right; we cannot see her face because it is covered by the head of a child of uncertain gender she embraces. This child is standing and may be gowned, although we can see little of this figure beyond the left side of his or her head and the left leg. These two figures seem to be seeking protection in each other's arms.

component.illusobjdesc: Just below line 1 is a winged dragon of a type traditionally called a wyvern. The creature is apparently flying through the air. It faces to the left, with a coiled or spiral tail with one loop on the right. Its skin looks scaly and its face is somewhat dog-like, with a partly opened mouth and large teeth. The top of the head bears a spiky crest. Its front paws look almost like human hands.

An old man descends head-first in the left margin. His gown forms a long, snake-like tail behind him. He has a long beard and long hair. His right arm is at his side, but we can see that, with his right hand, he grasps a large book or tablet. His left arm reaches downward and he holds in his left hand a scepter or spear with a fleur-de-lis point. This figure may be Albion's Angel or Urizen (twice referred to in the text) with his book of laws.
In the plate's lower margin is a landscape that includes three figures, probably a family group of father, mother, and child.

The male (perhaps the father) is the left-most figure in the family group, lower right. He is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent slightly forward and his face turned partly downward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture, and his crude facial features, express despair or terror.

The crouching female in the family group, lower right, is probably the mother. She may be gowned or nude. Her left knee and foot are prominent. She turns her head to the right; we cannot see her face because it is covered by the head of a child of uncertain gender she embraces.
The woman embraces a child of uncertain gender. This child is standing and may be gowned, although we can see little of this figure beyond the left side of his or her head and the left leg.
A jagged line below and to the left of the dragon's left paw may represent lightning.
A jagged line below the descending old man may represent lightning.
The sky is filled with the outlines of clouds.

The trunk of a large, fallen tree dominates the landscape, lower left. One short branch and at least two roots are pictured. Another fallen tree appears behind the figures on on the right. One branch extends upward and toward the right margin.

lg.l: Appear to the Americans upon the cloudy night.
Solemn heave the Atlantic waves between the gloomy nations
Swelling. belching from its deeps red clouds & raging fires,
Albion is sick. America faints! enrag'd the Zenith grew.
As human blood shooting its veins all round the orbed heaven
Red rose the clouds from the Atlantic in vast wheels of blood
And in the red clouds rose a Wonder o'er the Atlantic sea;
Intense! naked! a Human fire fierce glowing, as the wedge
Of iron heated in the furnace; his terrible limbs were fire
With myriads of cloudy terrors banners dark & towers
Surrounded; heat but not light went thro' the murky atmo-
-sphere
(vision
The King of England looking westward trembles at the

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-plate design with six nude and muscular male figures. Top left is a man hovering horizontally in the air in front of a cloud. His left leg extends back and up behind him; his left arm extends out to the right and he points in that direction with his left index finger. In his right hand he holds large scales (or, more precisely, a pair of balances), perhaps to be associated with the Day of Judgement. This figure may be a personification of Justice. He has long hair and looks up and to the right at the pair of figures to his right. The lower man in this pair seems to be standing, with one leg bent and one extended, on the outline of the cloud. He is bent over, with his face hidden. His hair is curly. With both arms bent at the elbows and extended over his head he carries on his back another nude male. This figure, in an extremely contracted posture, has his arms clasped behind his back, both legs drawn up, and his head and upper body bent over so that his head seems to touch his groin or left thigh. Perhaps we are to think that the man holding this figure is about to cast him into the abyss. Further to the right, but still above the text area, is another nude figure with long hair that forms loops. In spite of this feature, the musculature suggests a male. We see him from behind, floating vertically in the air, with legs slightly spread. His left arm is raised, his right is lowered, but he grasps with both hands a giant sword with flames emanating from its edge and trailing off to the right, as though blown by a wind. The arm position suggests that he may be sheathing the sword, although no sheath is clearly pictured. This figure, perhaps another personification of Justice, looks to the right. Below the text are large tongues of flame, perhaps suggesting hell. Just above these fires are two more nude males. The figure on the left hovers horizontally in the air, although he may be falling into the flames below. His hair is curly. His knees are drawn up toward his torso and he grasps the back of his head with both hands and faces down. This gesture suggests despair. To the right is a male falling head-first. His knees are sharply bent and he too seems to grasp his head with both hands. Around him circles a giant snake, with open mouth and a forked tongue. Below the human figure, the snake's tail forms a spiral into which the man may be falling. The skin of the snake is scaly.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude and muscular male hovers horizontally in the air in front of a cloud, top left corner of the plate. His left leg extends back and up behind him; his left arm extends out to the right and he points in that direction with his left index finger. In his right hand he holds large scales (or, more precisely, a pair of balances), perhaps to be associated with the Day of Judgement. This figure may be a personification of Justice. He has long hair and looks up and to the right at the pair of figures to his right.

The lower man in this pair of nude and muscular males seems to be standing, with his right leg drawn up and bent and his left leg extended, on the outline of the cloud. He is bent over, with his face hidden. His hair is curly. With both arms bent at the elbows and extended over his head he carries on his back another nude male. Perhaps we are to think that he is about to throw his victim into the abyss below.

A muscular nude male is held over the head of another male. He is in an extremely contracted posture, has his arms clasped behind his back, both legs drawn up, and his head and upper body bent over so that his head seems to touch his groin or left thigh. Perhaps we are to think that the man holding this figure is about to cast him into the abyss.

Although this nude figure's hair is long and forms loops, the musculature suggests another male. We see him from behind, hovering vertically in the air, with legs slightly spread. His left arm is raised, his right is lowered, but he grasps with both hands a giant sword with flames emanating from its edge and trailing off to the right, as though blown by a wind. The arm position suggests that he may be sheathing the sword, although no sheath is clearly pictured. This figure, perhaps another personification of Justice, looks to the right.

A muscular, nude male hovers horizontally in the air, although he may be falling into the flames below. His hair is curly. His knees are drawn up toward his torso and he grasps the back of his head with both hands and faces down. This gesture suggests despair.

A muscular, nude male falls head-first. His knees are sharply bent and he seems to grasp his head with both hands-- a gesture indicating despair. Around him circles a giant snake, with open mouth and a forked tongue. Below the human figure, the snake's tail forms a spiral into which the man may be falling.
A giant snake with open mouth and forked tongue almost completes a circle around the falling nude male. The snake's tail, into which the man may be falling, forms a spiral. The snake's skin is scaly.
A cloud hovers behind the man holding scales.
The flames emanating from the sword suggest a wind blowing from left to right.
The lower areas of the plate, right and left of the snake and falling man, contain tongues of fire. These may be the fires of hell.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Small vines follow lines 2 and 4 of the text. Another vine, perhaps with a few leaves, extends from the "l" of "planet" in line 4. A vine-like extension of the "p" in "temple" (line 10) curls to the left of the word.

component.illusobjdesc: Small vines follow lines 2 and 4 of the text. Another vine, perhaps with a few leaves, extends from the "l" of "planet" in line 4.
A vine-like extension of the "p" in "temple" (line 10) curls to the left of the word.

lg.l: Albions Angel stood beside the Stone
of night, and saw
The terror like a comet, or more like the
planet red
That once inclos'd the terrible wandering comets in its sphere.
Then Mars thou wast our center, & the planets three flew round
Thy crimson disk; so e'er the Sun was rent from thy red sphere;
The Spectre glowd his horrid length staining the temple long
With beams of blood; & thus a voice came forth, and shook the
temple

illustration.illusobjdesc: A youthful, muscular, nude male sits on the ground. His legs are bent at the knees, with thighs spread apart (clearly revealing his genitals) and his feet below the center of his body. His arms are behind him, apparently with hands resting on the ground for support (we see only his right hand on the ground). His hair is curly. His body is slightly twisted as he faces up and to the right. He may be in the act of rising from the ground. Behind are clouds; the earth below may be a small hill or mound. Below his right foot and on the right are several leaves, perhaps oak or grape leaves. A vine-like plant with leaves and perhaps flowers decorates the right side of the mound and descends into the right margin of the text. There may also be a few tufts of grass on the far right side of the mound. On the left is a skull, facing skyward. This motif suggests that the male may be sitting on a grave--perhaps his own, from which he is rising. Far left are a few tufts of grass and another vine dangling down the left margin of the text; it bears large leaves (perhaps grape).

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful, muscular, nude male sits on the ground. His legs are bent at the knees, with thighs spread apart (clearly revealing his genitals) and his feet below the center of his body. His arms are behind him, apparently with hands resting on the ground for support (we see only his right hand on the ground). His hair is curly. His body is slightly twisted as he faces up and to the right. He may be in the act of rising from the ground.
Clouds appear in the sky on both sides of the figure.
A human skull rests on the ground left of the seated man. The skull faces up.
The small hill or mound of earth on which the man sits may be a grave, given the presence of the skull on the left.
The surface texture of the mound on which the figure sits suggests grass or moss. There are two large leaves, perhaps oak or grape, below and to the left of his right foot.

The vegetation on the right side of the mound on which the man sits consists of two large (oak or grape?) leaves and a vine-like plant with leaves and perhaps small flowers. There may be a few tufts of grass far right. One stem of the vine forms loops; other stems descend into the right margin of the text.
The left side of the mound on which the man sits contains a few tufts of grass and a vine with large (grape?) leaves. This vine descends into the left margin of the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lower margin of the plate contains (from left to right) a small leafy plant, some tufts of grass, and a thistle with two large leaves and one flower. The animals include (left to right) a winged insect about to be eaten by a lizard, a frog or toad, and a small snake with its mouth open.

component.illusobjdesc: The lower margin of the plate contains (from left to right) a small leafy plant, some tufts of grass, and a thistle with two large leaves and one flower.
A small winged insect flies just above the ground left of the eager mouth of a lizard. The lizard faces left; its forked tongue is pictured.
A frog or toad sits on the ground beneath the thistle. He faces right and may be looking at a small snake rising on its curving body.
A small snake, facing left and with mouth open, rises on its curving body.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Extensions of letters on the first, second, and sixth words in line 1 are vine-like, with loops in the first and last of these motifs. The second letter of the first word in line 2 extends, vine-like, to the left; the extension of the first letter in line 10 is also vine-like.

component.illusobjdesc: Extensions of letters on the first, second, and sixth words in line 1 are vine-like, with loops in the first and last of these motifs. The second letter of the first word in line 2 extends, vine-like, to the left.
The extension of the first letter in line 10 is vine-like. Its shape suggests a spiral.

lg.l: The morning comes, the night decays, the watchmen leave
their stations;
The grave is burst, the spices shed, the linen wrapped up;
The bones of death, the cov'ring clay, the sinews shrunk & dry'd.
Reviving shake. inspiring move, breathing! awakening!
Spring like redeemed captives when their bonds & bars are burst;
Let the slave grinding at the mill, run out into the field;
Let him look up into the heavens & laugh in the bright air;
Let the inchained soul shut up in darkness and in sighing,
Whose face has never seen a smile in thirty weary years;
Rise and look out, his chains are loose, his dungeon doors are open
And let his wife and children return from the opressors scourge;
They look behind at every step & believe it is a dream.
Singing. The Sun has left his blackness, & has found a fresher morning
And the fair Moon rejoices in the clear & cloudless night;
For Empire is no more, and now the Lion & Wolf shall cease.

objnote.p: This object is a lithographic reproduction not by Blake; see Copy Information for details.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains seven lines of text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. The landscape below the text includes, on the left, a large tree, perhaps a birch or willow, growing up the left margin. Its long, slender branches and leaves (or perhaps catkins) arch over the text. Three birds, two with long, forked tails, are perched on the branches. One other bird flies in the air, plus a winged insect (perhaps a moth or butterfly). The landscape below includes grass and two large leaves. The leaf on the left, near the tree, has a vine-like stem; this may be a grape vine. The leaf in the lower right corner might be either a grape or oak leaf. Lying on the grass is a ram, facing right, apparently asleep. A young boy or male child rests his arms and head on the ram's back; his feet can be seen right of the ram's head. This boy has curly hair and is probably also sleeping. Below the ram, another youth, but of uncertain gender, is stretched on the grass, perhaps asleep. We see this nude figure from behind. The figure's left leg is extended, the right bent at the knee. The figure's head lies on his or her right arm; we see only the top of the figure's head and long hair. This gentle, pastoral scene contrasts sharply with the apocalyptic tone of the text on the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: The landscape below the text includes, on the left, a large tree, perhaps a birch or willow, growing up the left margin. Its long, slender branches and leaves (or perhaps catkins) arch over the text. Three birds, two with long, forked tails, sit on the branches.
The earth is covered with grasses. Those on each side of the tree are long.
A large leaf is supported by a long stem with one loop in it. This may be a grape vine.
A large leaf rests on the ground in the lower right corner of the plate. This may be a grape leaf (like the one near the tree on the left) or an oak leaf.

A bird soars upward on extended wings between the branches of the tree. Three birds, two with long forked tails, are perched on the branches of the tree. Left of the uppermost bird is a flying insect, perhaps a moth or butterfly.
A large ram with prominent horns sleeps on the ground. He faces to the right.
A young boy or male child rests his arms and head on the ram's back; his feet can be seen right of the ram's head. This boy has curly hair and is probably sleeping.

Below the ram, a nude youth or child of uncertain gender is stretched on the grass, perhaps asleep. We see this figure from behind. The figure's left leg is extended, the right bent at the knee. The figure's head lies on his or her right arm; we see only the top of the figure's head and long hair. The figure's body is somewhat twisted, with the legs and hips lying on their right side and the upper body lying prone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A loopy, vine-like extension decorates the first letter of the text; other vine-like extensions descend from the "y" of "Why" and the "y" of "eyes" in line 7.

component.illusobjdesc: A loopy, vine-like extension decorates the first letter of the text; other vine-like extensions descend from the "y" of "Why" and the "y" of "eyes" in line 7.

lg.l: In thunders ends the voice. Then Albions Angel wrathful burnt
Beside the Stone of Night; and like the Eternal Lions howl
In famine & war, reply'd. Art thou not Orc, who serpent-form'd
Stands at the gate of Enitharmon to devour her children;
Blasphemous Demon, Antichrist, hater of Dignities;
Lover of wild rebellion. and transgresser of Gods Law;
Why dost thou come to Angels eyes in this terrific form?

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains a good deal of text, Blake treated the pictorial image as a full-plate design. Above, an old, bearded, and gowned man sits among clouds. His long hair cascades over his left shoulder. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally; his hands seem to be holding the clouds on which they rest, palms down. His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This figure is very probably Urizen. At the bottom of the plate is a dark and stormy sea with waves. The text panel is shaped in such a way as to suggest a cloud between the upper and lower parts of the design, or possibly a break between clouds. The design, particularly the figure, offers a contrasting parallel to the design on object 12.

component.illusobjdesc: An old, bearded, and gowned man sits among clouds. His long hair cascades over his left shoulder. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally; his hands seem to be holding the clouds on which they rest, palms down. The visible fingers on his hands are spread apart. His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This is probably Urizen.
Below the text is a dark and stormy sea with waves.
Dense clouds form both the surface on which the figure sits and his background. The text panel is shaped like a cloud, or possibly a break between clouds.
A jagged line below "like silver" in line 17 suggests a bolt of lightning over the sea.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions spring from the first letter in line 1, the "O" of "Orc" (line 1), and the first letters in lines 9 and 12. All but the first include loops.

component.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions spring from the first letter in line 1, the "O" of "Orc," also in line 1. The latter includes one loop.
Vine-like extensions spring from the first letters in lines 9 and 12. Both include a loop.

lg.l: The terror answerd; I am Orc, wreath'd round the accursed tree:
The times are ended; shadows pass the morning gins to break;
The fiery joy, that Urizen perverted to ten commands,
What night he led the starry hosts thro' the wide wilderness:
That stony law I stamp to dust: and scatter religion abroad
To the four winds as a torn book, & none shall gather the leaves;
But they shall rot on desart sands, & consume in bottomless deeps,
To make the desarts blossom, & the deeps shrink to their fountains,
And to renew the fiery joy, and burst the stony roof.
That pale religious letchery, seeking Virginity,
May find it in a harlot, and in coarse-clad honesty
The undefil'd tho' ravish'd in her cradle night and morn:
For every thing that lives is holy, life delights in life;
Because the soul of sweet delight can never be defil'd.
Fires inwrap the earthly globe, yet man is not consumd;
Amidst the lustful fires he walks; his feet become like brass,
His knees and thighs like silver, & his breast and head like gold.

objnote.p: Plate 11 is in the second of two states, with additional white line work in the lower left margin and just above the bottom edge of the plate. The first state is found only in Copy L.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, the dense white-line hatching represents grain stems and tassels. Below one of the two arching clusters of grain is a nude infant or child, probably male, lying supine on the ground. His arms are at his side and his body is rigid; he may be dead. Right and left of the child are two plants with large leaves and vine-like tendrils. At least the plant on the right bears two flowers. Both plants have been identified as poppies. The white-line crosshatching extending up the left margin of the text might represent the clouds of an approaching storm, smoke, the sky, or simply the chaos of the material world.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant or child, probably male, lies supine on the ground below arching grain stems. His arms are at his side and his body is rigid; he may be dead.
Below the text, the dense white-line hatching represents grain stems and tassels. Two prominent clusters of stems arch over to the left.
Right and left of the child are two plants with large leaves and vine-like tendrils. At least the plant on the right bears two flowers on its loopy stems. Both plants have been identified as poppies.
The white-line crosshatching extending up the left margin of the text might represent the clouds of an approaching storm, smoke, the sky, or simply the chaos of the material world.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several letters begin or terminate with vine-like forms. The most prominent is the first letter of the first word in line 1, the last letter of "round" in line 7, and the middle letter of the second "the" in line 8. The right margin of the text is filled with vines, a few bearing leaves.

component.illusobjdesc: The letter "S" at the beginning of line 1 begins and terminates with vine-like forms, including one loop.
The final letter of "round" (line 7), has a vine trailing from its top. A vine sprouts from the middle letter of "the," second word from the end of line 8.
The right margin of the text is filled with vines, a few bearing leaves. One is looped.

lg.l: Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my Thirteen Angels!
Loud howls the eternal Wolf! the eternal Lion lashes his tail!
America is darkned; and my punishing Demons terrified
Crouch howling before their caverns deep like skins dry'd in the wind,
They cannot smite the wheat, nor quench the fatness of the earth,
They cannot smite with sorrows, nor subdue the plow and spade,
They cannot wall the city, nor moat round the castle of princes.
They cannot bring the stubbed oak to overgrow the hills.
For terrible men stand on the shores, & in their robes I see
Children take shelter from the lightnings, there stands Washington
And Paine and Warren with their foreheads reard toward the east
But clouds obscure my aged sight. A vision from afar!
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels:
Ah vision from afar! Ah rebel form that rent the ancient

Heavens! Eternal Viper self-renew'd, rolling in clouds Blake etched an exclamation mark after "Heavens," but in Copy E the vertical stroke was not inked, except for a bottom and top edge, and prints mostly as a blind embossment.
I see thee in thick clouds and darkness on America's shore.
Writhing in pangs of abhorred birth; red flames the crest rebellious
And eyes of death; the harlot womb oft opened in vain
Heaves in enormous circles, now the times are return'd upon thee,
Devourer of thy parent, now thy unutterable torment renews.
Sound! sound! my loud war trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels,
Ah terrible birth! a young one bursting! where is the weeping mouth?
And where the mother's milk? instead those ever-hissing jaws
And parched lips drop with fresh gore; now roll thou in the clouds
Thy mother lays her length outstretch'd upon the shore beneath.
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels!
Loud howls the eternal Wolf: the eternal Lion lashes his tail!

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. Below the text, a nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His left leg is bent at the knee, as though he were stepping up and rising; his right leg is covered by flames. This figure is very probably Orc, the spirit of revolution. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that emanate from beneath his prominent left foot. These flames (of hell?) extend up the left margin and appear in the spaces between the text, particularly between lines 4 and 5. The design offers a contrasting parallel to the design on object 10.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His left leg is bent at the knee, as though he were stepping up and rising; his right leg is covered by flames. This figure is very probably Orc, the spirit of revolution. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that emanate from beneath his prominent left foot.

The figure is surrounded by flames (of hell?) that emanate from below his left foot. The fires climb to the top of the plate along the left margin and appear in the upper right corner, between lines 4 and 5 of the text, and between lines 10 and 11 on the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines appear at the end of lines 6 and 8 of the text. The higher vine includes three loops. Extensions of letters at the beginning of lines 3 and 10 form vine-like tendrils. The extension of the "y" in the first word of line 10 forms a loop. A loopy vine extends from the second letter of "those" (line 5); the extensions of the first letter of "Golden" (line 7) are also vine-like.

component.illusobjdesc: Extensions of letters at the beginning of lines 3 and 10 form vine-like tendrils. The extension of the "y" in the first word of line 10 forms a loop. A loopy vine extends from the second letter of "those" in line 5.
Vines appear at the end of lines 6 and 8 of the text. The higher vine includes three loops. The extensions of the first letter of "Golden" (line 7) are also vine-like.

lg.l: Thus wept the Angel voice & as he wept the terrible blasts
Of trumpets, blew a loud alarm across the Atlantic deep.
No trumpets answer; no reply of clarions or of fifes,
Silent the Colonies remain and refuse the loud alarm.
On those vast shady hills between America & Albions shore;
Now barr'd out by the Atlantic sea: call'd Atlantean hills;
Because from their bright summits you may pass to the Golden world.
An ancient palace, archetype of mighty Emperies,
Rears its immortal pinnacles, built in the forest of God
By Ariston the king of beauty for his stolen bride,
Here on their magic seats the thirteen Angels sat perturb'd
For clouds from the Atlantic hover o'er the solemn roof,

objnote.p: The plate is in the second state of two, with one tail on the snake, lower left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full page design. Given the presence of stars and a crescent moon, this is a night scene. The sky is filled with clouds and the text panel is also shaped like a cloud. High in the sky, but below lines 1-4, a giant swan flies on extended wings to the right. A youthful nude male rides on his back. The figure's legs are spread apart and dangle on each side of the swan's back just in front of its wings. The youth's hair, blown to the left by the onward flight of the bird, may be curly. He looks back to the left, away from the direction of flight, and braces himself with his right arm. His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds in his left hand a rein attached to the swan's beak. This figure has sometimes been identified as Boston's Angel, although the reason for this may be nothing more than the fact that he is named in the text immediately above the figure. To the right of the swan are four much smaller birds, all flying on extended wings. The largest of these has a forked tail. Below, and to the left of the text panel, are seven stars; these may be a constellation, the Pleiades. Below the text, but still in the night sky, are two more flying birds and, on the right, the crescent moon and a single star (or perhaps the planet Venus). The earth appears only along the lower margin; on the far right are a few spiky lines indicating vegetation. Three nude children ride on the back of a snake. The front-most child, perhaps a girl with long hair, holds a pair of reins in her left hand that extends to the snake's open mouth. Its forked tongue is prominent. The second child, further to the left, appears to be a male. He braces himself with his left arm, perhaps holding on to the snake with his left hand, and reaches back with his right arm to hold hands with the very young child or infant nearest the snake's tail. This child reaches up, perhaps with both hands, but faces to the right and may be looking down. The right-most child has her legs together; the others have their legs spread on each side of the snake (although we see only their right legs). The snake's body forms a loop left of the children and terminates in two more loops.

component.illusobjdesc: Most of the design consists of the sky filled with clouds. The text panel is also shaped as a cloud. Given the presence of stars and a crescent moon, this would appear to be a night scene.
A single rein extends from the swan's beak to the rider's left hand.
A pair of reins extends from the snake's mouth to the left hand of the child nearest the snake's head.
Seven stars appear in the night sky in the left margin of the text. This may be a constellation, the Pleiades.
A single star (or perhaps the planet Venus) appears in the night sky just above the snake's head.
A crescent moon appears in the night sky.
A giant swan flies to the right on extended wings. The bird is ridden by a youthful male who holds a single rein attached to the partly-opened beak of the swan.
Four birds fly on extended wings right of the giant swan. Three birds are very small; the fourth is fairly large and has a prominent forked tail.
Two birds fly through the sky on extended wings between the last line of text and the snake below. The bird on the right may have a forked tail.

A giant snake glides along the ground, probably moving to the right. Its mouth is open and its forked tongue is clearly pictured. Hatching marks suggest a scaly body. The snake's body on the left forms a single loop and, further to the left, two loops.
A few etched lines right of the snake suggest vegetation, perhaps spiky grass.

A youthful and muscular nude male rides on the swan's back. The figure's legs are spread apart and they dangle on each side of the swan's back just in front of its wings. The youth's hair may be curly. He looks back to the left, away from the direction of flight, and braces himself with his right arm. His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds in his left hand a rein attached to the swan's beak. This figure has sometimes been identified as Boston's Angel, although the reason for this may be nothing more than the fact that he is named in the text immediately above the figure.

A nude child, perhaps female, rides on the back of the snake nearest his head. She holds in her raised left hand a pair of reins attached to the snake's mouth. Her legs are together; her right arm is either at her side or behind her back and braced on the snake's back. She looks to the right; her long hair trails to the left.

A nude child, probably male, rides on the back of the snake. His legs are spread apart. He braces himself with his left arm and may be holding onto the snake with his left hand. He reaches back with his right hand to hold the hand of the child or infant to the left.

A very young nude child or infant of uncertain gender rides on the snake's back nearest its tail. He or she faces to the right and raises his or her right arm to hold hands with the child further to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several motifs follow the end of line 8 of the text. These are, from left to right, a stick figure with arms raised horizontally and striding to the left; a vine, perhaps with leaves, on which the figure walks; a vine with a loop, extending upward from the "d" of "commanded" in the line below; a mammal of some sort (a horse or fox?) with a bushy tail, running or leaping to the left; a vine extending from the "h" of "what" in line 9; and a series of swirls that may represent vines. Three birds fly above "the energies" (line 11); two fly above "and generosity" (line 12). Many letters bear vine-line extensions; those at the beginning of lines 1 and 13 contain loops, as does the vine extending above "& the" (line 13). The vine arching over "frowns" (line 6) may bear small leaves. There is a detached vine above "abstinence & wraps" (line 16).

component.illusobjdesc: At the end of line 8 of the text, a stick figure with arms raised horizontally strides to the left.
At the end of line 8 of the text, and right of the human figure, a mammal of some sort, perhaps a horse or fox with a bushy tail, runs or leaps to the left.

The motifs following line 8 include three vines, one between the man and the animal extending from the "d" of "commanded" in the line below, one extending from the "h" of "what" in the line below, and the largest above the last three words of line 9. All contain loops.
Three birds fly above "the energies" (line 11); two fly above "and generosity" (line 12).

Many letters bear vine-line extensions; those at the beginning of lines 1 and 13 contain loops, as does the vine extending above "& the" (line 13). The vine arching over "frowns" (line 6) may bear small leaves. There is a detached vine above "abstinence & wraps" (line 16).

lg.l: Fiery the Angels rose, & as they rose deep thunder roll'd
Around their shores; indignant burning with the fires of Orc
And Bostons Angel cried aloud as they flew thro' the dark
night,
He cried: Why trembles honesty and like a murderer,
Why seeks he refuge from the frowns of his immortal station,
Must the generous tremble & leave his joy, to the idle: to
the pestilence!
That mock him? who commanded this, what God! what Angel!
To keep the gen'rous from experience till the ungenerous
Are unrestraind performers of the energies of nature;
Till pity is become a trade, and generosity a science,
That men get rich by, & the sandy desart is giv'n to the strong
What God is he, writes laws of peace, & clothes him in a tempest
What pitying Angel lusts for tears, and fans himself with sighs
What crawling villain preaches abstinence & wraps himself
In fat of lambs? no more I follow, no more obedience pay,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design. Lower left, an old man enters a tomb.
