The post and lintel doorway, very probably built of stones, makes the tomb look like the entrance to a mine shaft. The heavy wooden door is partly open, revealing within darkness and, lower left, either another stone or perhaps the edge of a bier. The old, bearded man wears a heavy gown; his prominent left foot can be seen under the hem. He faces, and is probably walking, to the left--into the tomb. He is bent over and leans on a crutch held in his left hand and propped beneath his left armpit. His hair appears to be blown by a wind from right to left, and hence towards the tomb entrance. To the right of the tomb is the trunk of a massive tree with a root extending along the ground to the right. The tree apparently continues behind the tomb and then grows above it, where we see more of the trunk, one large, leafless branch that arches over the text, and the leaves from another branch. Behind and to the right of the lower trunk of the tree is a form that may be another tree trunk or a cliff. Further to the right below the text is a dark and stormy sky with heavy clouds. A few vague forms on the horizon may be trees.

component.illusobjdesc: An old, bearded man wearing a heavy gown walks to the left and into the entrance to a tomb. His prominent left foot can be seen under the hem of his garment. He is bent over and leans on a crutch held in his left hand and propped beneath his left armpit. His hair appears to be blown by a wind from right to left, and hence towards the tomb entrance.
Small shadows extend to the left from the old man's left foot and crutch.

The old man enters a tomb. The post and lintel doorway, very probably built of stones, makes the tomb look like the entrance to a mine shaft. The heavy wooden door is partly open, revealing within darkness and, lower left, either another stone or perhaps the edge of a bier. There are slight indications of a large hinge on the door just above the figure's back.
Within the tomb, lower left, we can see what may be another building stone or perhaps the corner of a bier.
To the right of the large tree trunk are some hatching lines that may represent another tree or a cliff.
The distant view on the lower right side of the plate shows a dark and stormy sky with heavy clouds.

To the right of the tomb is the trunk of a massive tree with a root extending along the ground to the right. The tree apparently continues behind the tomb and then grows above it, where we see more of the trunk, one large, leafless branch that arches over the text, and the leaves from another branch.
A few odd forms on the horizon may be a clump of trees.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vegetative forms decorate the text. The most prominent are the vine (or perhaps a worm?) descending from the first letter of the first line; two vines between lines 6 and 8; and a vine or worm extending from the last letter of "its" in line 12, very close to the right margin of the plate. The extension of the final letter of "cried" (line 1) forms a loop; other vegetative forms appear above "rending" (line 1), above the second ampersand in line 9, as an extension of the first letter in line 10, and above "furnace" in line 15.

component.illusobjdesc: The wavy line descending from the first letter of line 1 may be a worm or a vine.
Two vines extend horizontally between lines 6 and 8 of the text. The vine on the right may bear leaves.
A vine or worm descends from the last letter of "its" in line 12 of the text, very close to the right margin of the plate.

The extension of the final letter of "cried" (line 1) forms a loop; other vegetative forms appear above "rending" (line 1), above the second ampersand in line 9, as an extension of the first letter in line 10, and above "furnace" in line 15.

lg.l: So cried he, rending off his robe & throwing down his scepter.
In sight of Albions Guardian, and all the thirteen Angels
Rent off their robes to the hungry wind, & threw their golden scep-
-ters
Down on the land of America. indignant they descended
Headlong from out their heav'nly heights, descending swift as
fires
Over the land; naked & flaming are their lineaments seen
In the deep gloom, by Washington & Paine & Warren they stood
And the flame folded roaring fierce within the pitchy night
Before the Demon red, who burnt towards America,
In black smoke thunders and loud winds rejoicing in its
terror
Breaking in smoky wreaths from the wild deep. & gath'ring thick
In flames as of a furnace on the land from North to South

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-page design showing the surface and bottom of the sea. Above the text, the limp body of a nude female lies supine on a stony shore, with her legs on the right extending into the waves of the sea. Her head is bent back and her long hair descends below, as does her dangling right arm. She is probably dead, perhaps from drowning. A plant with spiky leaves and a vine grow left of the woman's head. A large bird, very probably an eagle, is perched on her right upper leg. The eagle's wings are extended and his curved beak seems to be thrust into the woman's abdomen. The bird may be eating the corpse; indeed, a triangular form below his beak may be a piece of her flesh. The sky behind the bird is filled with clouds; the sea on the right (perhaps the Atlantic, named several times in the text) is stormy. Below the text we see the dark waters of the deep and the bottom of the sea. Upon it lies supine a nude male, with his knees bent slightly and his left arm at his side. His body is emaciated and rigid; he is no doubt dead, probably from drowning. We can see his ribs and his fingers look skeletal, perhaps because the sea creatures around him have been eating his flesh. These include one large fish and two small ones, all with their mouths open. A sea snake coils itself around the man's legs; another snake hovers above his chest. Five much smaller fish appear immediately below the text and in the right margin following lines 17-18. Below the man, on the floor of the sea, are two further sea snakes or worms. Near the lower right corner is a large, spiral shell, probably a whelk (common to the Atlantic). In the far lower right corner is a minimally-representational form that may be another shell. Vegetation rises in the left margin of the text almost touching the female figure on the rocky shore. This vegetation may be seaweed. The twisted lines include, left of lines 5-8 of the text, a snake with open mouth.

component.illusobjdesc: The limp body of a nude female lies supine on a rocky shore, with her legs on the right extending into the waves of the sea. Her head is bent back and her long hair descends below, as does her dangling right arm. She is probably dead, perhaps from drowning. The eagle perched on her body may be eating her flesh. Her right breast is prominent.

A nude male lies supine on the floor of the sea. His knees are bent slightly and his left arm is at his side. His body is emaciated and rigid; he is no doubt dead, probably from drowning. We can see his ribs and his fingers look skeletal, perhaps because the sea creatures around him have been eating his flesh. A sea snake is entwined around and binds his legs.
A plant with spiky leaves and a vine grow left of the woman's head.

A large bird, very probably an eagle, is perched on the right upper leg of the nude female. The bird's body faces forward, but its head is turned to the left. We can see one of his talons on her leg. The eagle's wings are extended and his curved beak seems to be thrust into the woman's abdomen. The bird may be eating the corpse; indeed, a triangular form below his beak may be a piece of her flesh.
Five small fish swim to the left just below line 18 and in the right margin following lines 17-18. A few have scales.

Two fish, one very large, swim to the right above the male corpse. A smaller fish swims to the left above the corpse's head. All three fish have their mouths open; the largest may have teeth. They may be feeding on the dead body. All bear slight indications of scales.
A sea snake swims above the male corpse. The snake's mouth is slightly open. Its tail suggests a spiral.
A sea snake coils itself around the legs of the male corpse. The snake's mouth is slightly open.
Two sea snakes or worms appear on the floor of the sea beneath the human corpse.

The curving line left of lines 5-8 in the text is a snake with two loops in its body and facing to the right with mouth open. The snake's body is intertwined with the flag or vine extending from the first letter of line 8.
The spiral shell near the lower right corner of the plate may be from a whelk. However, the shell looks empty, and thus the whelk has died.
Vegetation--probably seaweed--grows up the left margin of the text. These vine-line plants include at least one loop.
The upper body of the female corpse rests on the stony shore of the sea.
The sky is filled with stormy clouds.
The sea--perhaps the Atlantic (frequently named in the text)--is filled with storm-tossed waves.
The surface of the dark water below the text shows indications of waves.
The minimally-representational form in the far lower right corner of the plate may be a shell.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text area contains several representational motifs, mostly vines. The first letter of the first word in line 2 sprouts into two vines, one with a flower or leaf at its termination (on the left) and one with two loops (on the right). The final letter of "England" in line 2 grows into a vine with one loop. Between lines 3 and 5 is a row of vines, some with leaves. Sitting on one such vine, just right of the word "cry" (line 4), is a small figure with legs spread, left arm raised horizontally, and right arm raised at 45 degrees (assuming that the figure is facing forward, which seems likely). Two large leaves complete this row of motifs; a worm or caterpillar rises above the leaf on the left. The first letter in line 7 extends into a looping vine. A vine extends from the last letter of "all," end of line 7. A bird flies at the end of line 5; another may be represented by the similar shape just above the right tip of the large leaf above the first bird. A vine, possibly with a leaf, extends from the first letter in line 15.

component.illusobjdesc: To the right of the word "cry" (line 4), carried over to its own line, a small figure sits on a vine with legs spread apart, left arm raised horizontally, and right arm raised at 45 degrees (assuming that the figure is facing forward, which seems likely).

The first letter in line 2 sprouts into two vines. The vine on the left terminates in a flower or leaf; the vine on the right forms two loops. The first letter in line 7 extends into a looping vine. The flag or vine extending from the first letter in line 8 is intertwined with the body of the snake in the margin.
The last letter of "England" in line 2 grows into a vine with a single loop.
The space between lines 3 and 5 is filled with vine-like forms, some including leaves. Two large leaves end this group, close to the right margin of the plate.
The last word in line 7 ("all") terminates in a vine extending horizontally to the right margin of the plate.
A bird flies at the end of line 5; another may be represented by the similar shape just above the right tip of the large leaf above the first bird.
A worm or caterpillar rises above the leaf below "they" in line 3.
A vine, possibly with a leaf, extends from the first letter in line 15.

lg.l: -vene
What time the thirteen Governors that England sent con-
In Bernards house; the flames coverd the land, they rouze they
cry
Shaking their mental chains they rush in fury to the sea
To quench their anguish; at the feet of Washington down fall'n
They grovel on the sand and writhing lie. while all
The British soldiers thro' the thirteen states sent up a howl
Of anguish: threw their swords & muskets to the earth & ran
From their encampments and dark castles seeking where to hide
From the grim flames; and from the visions of Orc; in sight
Of Albions Angel; who enrag'd his secret clouds open'd
From north to south, and burnt outstretchd on wings of wrath cov'ring
The eastern sky, spreading his awful wings across the heavens;
Beneath him rolld his num'rous hosts, all Albions Angels camp'd
Darkend the Atlantic mountains & their trumpets shook the valleys
Arm'd with diseases of the earth to cast upon the Abyss,
Their numbers forty millions, must'ring in the eastern sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the design appears between lines 9 and 10 of the text, but the roots of the large tree descend to the lower margin and its branches extend to the top. Thus, one must view the entire plate to see all elements of the design. Under the arching and leafless branches of this tree sits a figure, probably female. Immediately behind her may be the trunk of a second large tree. She is nude except for a long scarf she wears over her head; it trails on the ground to the right. Her legs are spread apart and bent at the knees, with her lower legs and feet drawn up near her thighs. She looks to the left toward the second figure in the design. Her left arm is braced next to her torso, with the left hand on the ground. Her right arm is extended horizontally, with the palm of her right hand facing down and her fingers (except for her downward-pointing thumb) pointing towards the other figure. She may be a sibyl or priestess. Between her legs is a coiled snake, with its head also directed at the second figure. The snake's mouth is open and its forked tongue is prominent. To the left is a young male with curly hair. He wears either a short gown or tights. He is seated on the ground, with his legs extended to the left and his upper body raised and twisted so that he faces right and looks toward the other figure. His hands are together in an attitude of prayer or supplication. His elbows are propped on a stack of two large books (or a tablet and a book on top). He may be a student or acolyte of the priestess. The sky behind the figures is filled with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant tree grows near the center right margin of the plate. Its bare branches ascend in the right margin to the top of the plate; its twisted roots descend to the bottom of the plate. Other leafless branches arch to the left over the two human figures.
The trunk of a second large tree may be the form immediately behind the back of the seated figure with the snake.

A figure, probably female, sits beneath the overhanging limb of the large tree. She is nude except for a long scarf she wears over her head; it trails on the ground to the right. Her legs are spread apart and bent at the knees, with her lower legs and feet drawn up near her thighs. She looks to the left toward the second figure in the design. Her left arm is braced next to her torso, with the left hand on the ground. Her right arm is extended horizontally, with the palm of her right hand facing down and her fingers (except for her downward-pointing thumb) pointing towards the other figure. She may be a sibyl or priestess. Between her legs is a coiled snake, with its head also directed at the second figure.

A young male with curly hair sits on the ground. He wears either a short gown or tights. His legs extend to the left and his upper body is raised and twisted so that he faces right and looks toward the other figure. His hands are together in an attitude of prayer or supplication. His elbows are propped on a stack of two large books (or a tablet and a book on top). He may be a student or acolyte of the priestess or sibyl on the right.
The young male has his arms propped on two books--or a tablet and a book on top.
A snake coils itself between the legs of the seated woman. Its head points to the left; its mouth is open and its forked tongue is prominent.
Clouds fill the sky behind the two figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fish or legless dragon with scaly skin faces left with open mouth. From its mouth issues a tongue of fire. A crest, like a dorsal fin, decorates its back.

component.illusobjdesc: A fish or legless dragon with scaly skin faces left with open mouth. From its mouth issues a tongue of fire. A crest, like a dorsal fin, decorates its back.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A line of motifs appears above the first line of text. From left to right, these are a hovering figure facing right with at least one arm raised horizontally, a vine with leaves and perhaps a grain tassel, a cluster of vines and leaves, a bird flying upward on extended wings, a vine with one loop, a human figure, perhaps gowned and facing left with one arm raised horizontally, and finally two vines or slender leaves. At the end of line 2 of the text is a vine with one loop. In line 5, a vine with loops and one leaf grows from the final letter of "as." In line 7, a vine with two loops grows from the second letter of "above." Another looped vine grows from the "s" of "as," line 9. A flag-like extension of the final letter of "earth" (line 15) extends over the word; another flag or leaf hovers vertically at the end of line 16. There is a row of representational forms between lines 16 and 17. These are, from left to right, a vine with loops, another vine, a bird flying upwards on extended wings, and a long vine with loops descending at the ends of lines 17-18.

component.illusobjdesc: A hovering figure, facing to the right and with at least one arm raised horizontally, appears above the second and third words in the first line of text. She or he may be wearing a gown that forms a curled tail. The figure may be holding something in his or her extended hand.

A small figure, facing to the left and with one arm raised horizontally, hovers above the words "drawn out" in line 1. The figure's legs are probably spread apart. Wisps of drapery below the figure suggest a gown, although this may only be a leaf below the figure.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above "armies" in line 1.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above "lost" in line 17.
The interlinear decorations above line 1 include several vines. The vine above "stood" includes a loop, a leaf, and perhaps a grain tassel. The cluster above "view'd" includes leaves.
A vine with a single loop follows line 2.
A vine with four loops and a single leaf grows from the second letter of "as" (line 5).
A vine with two loops grows from the second letter of "above" in line 7. A vine with a single loop extends from the second the "s" of "as" (line 9).
A flag-like extension of the final letter of "earth" (line 15) extends over the word; another flag or leaf hovers vertically at the end of line 16.
Three vines appear between lines 16 and 17. The vine on the left contains loops. The long vine on the right descends in loops into the margin following lines 17- 18.

lg.l: In the flames stood & view'd the armies drawn out in the sky
Washington Franklin Paine & Warren Allen Gates & Lee:
And heard the voice of Albions Angel give the thunderous command
His plagues obedient to his voice flew forth out of their clouds
Falling upon America, as a storm to cut them off
As a blight cuts the tender corn when it begins to appear.
Dark is the heaven above, & cold & hard the earth beneath;
And as a plague wind fill'd with insects cuts off man & beast;
And as a sea o'erwhelms a land in the day of an earthquake;
Fury! rage! madness! in a wind swept through America
And the red flames of Orc that folded roaring fierce around
The angry shores, and the fierce rushing of th' inhabitants together;
The citizens of New-York close their books & lock their chests;
The mariners of Boston drop their anchors and unlade;
The scribe of Pensylvania casts his pen upon the earth;
The builder of Virginia throws his hammer down in fear.
Then had America been lost, o'erwhelm'd by the Atlantic,
And Earth had lost another portion of the infinite,
But all rush together in the night in wrath and raging fire
The red fires rag'd! the plagues recoil'd! then rolld they back
with fury

objnote.p: There are pencil sketches, not by Blake, on the verso of Object 17; see Related Works in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper left margin of the plate, a gowned figure, probably female, sits on the ground with her knees drawn up and her upper body and head leaning forward at a sharp angle. Her body faces right in this very contracted posture; her face is covered by her right knee. She may be mourning or sunk into despair. To the right of her is a plant with leaves and perhaps a flower at its top. To the left of the figure is a tree entwined with a vine. The tree apparently has long, slender leaves on its drooping branches. Above the figure, near the top left corner of the plate, a bird is either perching on the tree or flying upward on extended wings.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure, probably female, sits on the ground with her knees drawn up and her upper body and head leaning forward at a sharp angle. Her body faces right in this very contracted posture; her face is covered by her right knee. She may be mourning or sunk into despair.
Near the top left corner of the plate, a bird with extended wings is either perched on the branch of the tree or is flying upwards.
To the right of the seated figure is a plant with leaves and perhaps a flower at its top.

To the left of the figure is a tree entwined with a vine. The tree apparently has long, slender leaves on its drooping branches. A slender vine, with perhaps two leaves at its top end, is intertwined around this tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the middle of the left margin of the plate, we see a nude female figure from behind. Her arms, raised vertically, vegetate into vines or the limbs of trees; her feet are becoming roots. This transformation suggests the classical myth of Daphne. Her legs are together and she faces to the right in a twisted posture. The vegetation or limb extending from her right arm bears two figures: a seated adult, probably female, facing left and holding a child or infant who stands on her lap. Left of the Daphne-figure's left leg is another small figure, probably a female child. This figure, also nude, faces up and reaches up with at least her right arm. This arm and her right leg may be vegetating, as with the major figure. Left of this small figure is a vine with one loop.

component.illusobjdesc: Near the middle of the left margin of the plate, we see a nude female figure from behind. Her arms, raised vertically, vegetate into vines or the limbs of trees; her feet are becoming roots. This transformation suggests the classical myth of Daphne. Her legs are together and she faces to the right, her body twisted.

The vegetation or limb extending from the right arm of the largest figure in the middle of the left margin bears two very small figures: a seated adult, probably female, facing left and holding a child or infant on her lap.

The vegetation or limb extending from the right arm of the largest figure in the middle of the left margin bears two very small figures, including an infant or child standing, and being held, in the lap of a woman.

In the figure group in the middle of the left margin, left of the largest figure's left leg, is a much smaller figure, probably a female child. This figure, also nude, faces up and reaches up with at least her right arm. This arm may be vegetating into a branch, as with the major figure.
A twisting vine with one loop appears near the middle of the left margin of the plate. It does not seem to be part of the vegetation into which the major figure is being transformed.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five nude female figures appear in flames in the design below the text. On the left, a female with legs slightly spread appears to be hovering in the flames or rising through them. Her arms are at her side; her long hair cascades over both shoulders. She is facing up and to the left. In the middle of the design is a group of three embracing females. The largest sits or squats, facing right but with her head lowered. She has long hair. We cannot see her face or arm positions. In her lap lies another nude female embracing the seated figure around her waist with her left arm, raised horizontally. Her body is twisted and her face is also hidden. The right-most figure in the group is facing forward but her head is twisted toward the seated figure. This final female also has long hair; she may be sitting or standing with her legs bent slightly. Her left arm is extended horizontally. To the right of this group is another nude female in an extremely contracted posture, facing left. Her legs are drawn up with her knees to her chest. Her upper body leans forward over her raised knees and her left arm partly encircles her lowered head and long hair. Between the ascending figure on the left and the group of three females is a large grape leaf, a spiraling grape vine, and a large cluster of grapes. Above the group of three is another spiraling grape vine. The fires may be both the "flames of Orc" (line 13) and the "fires of hell" (line 17).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female with legs slightly spread appears to be hovering in flames or rising through them. Her arms are at her side; her long hair cascades over both shoulders. She is facing up and to the left.
Three nude females cluster together in a group.
The largest nude female in the group of three sits or squats, facing right with her head lowered. She has long hair. We cannot see her face or arm positions.

In the group of three nude females, one kneels with her right leg drawn up and lies in the lap of the seated woman. She embraces the seated figure around her waist with her left arm, raised horizontally. Her body is twisted and her face is hidden.

The right-most nude female in the group is facing forward but her head is twisted toward the seated figure. This woman also has long hair; she may be sitting, kneeling, or standing. Her left arm is slightly bent and extended horizontally to the left.

To the right of the group of three is another nude female in an extremely contracted posture, facing left. Her legs are drawn up with her knees to her chest. Her upper body leans forward over her knees and her left arm partly encircles her lowered head and long hair.
The figures in the design below the text are surrounded by fire. These may be both the "flames of Orc" (line 13) and the "fires of hell" (line 17).
Between the ascending figure on the left and the group of three females is a large grape leaf, a spiraling grape vine, and a large cluster of grapes.
A spiraling vine, perhaps another grape vine, appears above the group of three females.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text includes, between its lines and in the right margin, a great many interlinear motifs. Most of these take the form of vines or other vegetation; only the most significant of these will be recorded here. Above the second word ("Albions") in line l, a bird flies upward on extended wings. The first letter of the first word in line 2 grows into a vine, perhaps with leaves. Line 3 is preceded by a horse running or leaping to the left. Following "Bristols" (line 3) are the following, reading left to right: a vine with a standing figure facing left, perhaps looking at a very small figure looking right with arms raised horizontally; a vine with a seated figure facing right; a flock of birds; a vine with perhaps a dog standing on it, facing left (and barking at the birds?); a vine with a standing figure facing left with at least one arm raised horizontally; a small bird and a large bird (an eagle?) flying upward; a tree trunk with one bare branch; a figure striding to the left, at least one arm raised vertically, holding something (perhaps a child?) in his or her raised hand. Two birds fly on extended wings above "And cast" in line 7. Following the word "mail" (line 6) is another series of very small motifs. These are, from left to right: a leafless tree; a minimally representational form that may be a figure sitting on the ground with one arm propping up the upper body; two figures facing each other, perhaps coming together to embrace or to fight; a vine with one leaf; a vine with two loops and one leaf; a vine-like form with a figure above it, striding and facing to the left with at least one arm raised horizontally; a vine bearing, and arching over, a figure lying on it and facing left. Following line 8 is a vine, growing from the second letter of "chattering" in line 9, and a hovering figure, with legs spread, facing to the left and holding to his or her mouth (and thus playing?) a trumpet or horn of some sort. A vine with two loops extends to the left from the first letter of "hills" (line 12). At the end of this line, a twisting vine appears above the final word ("sky"). A tassel of grain grows from the final letter of "sky." Between lines 12 and 13 are several motifs. From left to right these are a vine with two loops growing from the first letter of "The" at the beginning of line 13; a very small figure striding to the right, with at least one arm raised horizontally, on top of the first letter of the first word in line 13; two vines, one with two loops; a small bird flying; a seated human figure with knees bent, at least one arm raised horizontally, and facing to the left; a vine with leaves growing from the "d" of "winds" in line 13; a vine or grain tassel growing from the first letter of "driven" in line 13; and a bird flying on extended wings above "flames" in line 13. A vine, with flowers or leaves, descends from the last letter of "scales" (line 21). Birds fly on extended wing above "spirits" and "dead pining" (line 25). Above "bonds of" in the same line, a stag runs or leaps to the left. A bird--or perhaps a moth--flies at the end of the line. A vine-like form with one loop connects the last letters of lines 24 and 28.

A figure, facing to the left, stands with legs spread above "spears" (line 7). The figure, with left arm raised horizontally and right arm raised at 135 degrees, may be striding to the right to embrace or fight the figure to the left.

A figure lies on a vine, the upper part of which arches over him or her, above "multitude" (line 7).
A vine follows the end of line 8. It grows from the second letter of "chattering" in line 9.

In the right margin, following line 8 and above the end of "chattering" in line 9, hovers a figure with legs spread and facing left. She or he holds to his or her mouth, and apparently plays, a trumpet or horn of some sort.

A vine with two loops appears above "plagues creep on" (line 13).
A small bird flies on extending wings above "on the" (line 13).
A figure sits on an extension from the "h" of the second "the" in line 13. He or she has legs bent at the knee and faces to the left with at least one arm raised horizontally.
A vine, perhaps with leaves, grows from the "d" of "winds" (line 13).
A vine or grain tassel grows from the first letter of "driven" (line 13).
A bird flies on extended wings above "flames" (line 13).
A vine, perhaps with leaves or flowers, descends from the last letter of "scales" (line 21).
A vine with one loop grows from the last letter of the last word ("youth") in line 24 of the text and is attached at its lower end to the last letter of the last word ("appears") in line 28.
A bird flies on extended wings above "spirits" (line 25).
A bird flies on extended wings above "dead pining" (line 25).

lg.l: On Albions Angels: then the Pestilence began in streaks of red
Across the limbs of Albions Guardian, the spotted plague smote
Bristols
And the Leprosy Londons Spirit, sickening all their bands:
The millions sent up a howl of anguish and threw off their ham-
-merd mail,
And cast their swords & spears to earth, & stood a naked multitude.
Albions Guardian writhed in torment on the eastern sky
Pale quivring toward the brain his glimmering eyes, teeth chattering
Howling & shuddering his legs quivering; convuls'd each muscle & sinew
Sick'ning lay Londons Guardian. and the ancient miter'd York
Their heads on snowy hills, their ensigns sick'ning in the sky
The plagues creep on the burning winds driven by flames of Orc,
And by the fierce Americans rushing together in the night
Driven o'er the Guardians of Ireland and Scotland and Wales
They spotted with plagues forsook the frontiers & their banners seard
With fires of hell, deform their ancient heavens with shame & woe,
Hid in his caves the Bard of Albion felt the enormous plagues.
And a cowl of flesh grew o'er his head & scales on his back & ribs;
And rough with black scales all his Angels fright their ancient heavens
The doors of marriage are open, and the Priests in rustling scales
Rush into reptile coverts, hiding from the fires of Orc,
That play around the golden roofs in wreaths of fierce desire,
Leaving the females naked and glowing with the lusts of youth
For the female spirits of the dead pining in bonds of religion;
Run from their fetters reddening, & in long drawn arches sitting:
They feel the nerves of youth renew, and desires of ancient times;
Over their pale limbs as a vine when the tender grape appears

illustration.illusobjdesc: A giant figure, wearing a gown and probably female, crouches on the ground in an extremely contracted posture. Her legs are bent under her body and her upper body is bent forward at a sharp angle over her legs. She faces right but her head faces down; her face is covered by her right arm, bent at the elbow with the upper arm raised. Apparently, her hands are together in an attitude of prayer or supplication. Her long hair cascades below her right elbow and down the right margin of the text, perhaps transformed into a waterfall. Despair and crying are suggested by the figure; perhaps we are to think of the waterfall as her tears. The figure has been variously identified as a personification of Earth (given the presence of other figures on her body) and even as Urizen, in spite of the apparent gender. Seven figures stand or sit on the giant's body. On her head is a seated figure, facing right and holding (and apparently reading) a book or tablet. On her back are two figures, one standing and facing right. This apparently gowned figure holds a book or tablet in her or his right hand. Just to the right is a kneeling figure, with one leg extended back, and the right arm raised at 135 degrees. This figure may be looking up and supplicating or praying. Below these two figures, and standing on the giant figure's right upper thigh, is a tree with three branches (but no leaves). Standing and leaning against this tree is a (probably male) figure facing to the right. He wears a broad-brimmed hat and holds and plays a pipe. Further down the giant's thigh are a few forms that may be sheep lying (and sleeping?) on her body. Thus, the piper is probably a shepherd. Below the piper, a very small figure lies on the giant's calf, facing right. This too may be a shepherd, given the presence of a few forms to the right that may be lying (and sleeping?) sheep. Just to the left of the giant's right foot is an embracing couple. The figure most likely to be the female in this group is seated with at least one leg bent at the knee, head facing down, and left arm raised horizontally to embrace her companion. The man kneels on the ground, facing right, with his right arm extended at 45 degrees to touch the woman's left thigh. To the right of this couple, and standing on the ground just beneath the giant's lower leg, a stag runs or leaps to the right. The left portion of this design above the text is a forest of at least four leafless trees. Their trunks have anthropomorphic forms. We can also see some of their roots near the left margin; one such root extends left of the first nine lines of text in the left margin. The ground near the right margin apparently descends over a cliff.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant figure, wearing a gown and probably female, crouches on the ground in an extremely contracted posture. Her legs are bent under her body and her upper body is bent forward at a sharp angle over her legs. She faces right but her head faces down; her face is covered by her right arm, bent at the elbow with the upper arm raised. Apparently, her hands are together in an attitude of prayer or supplication. Her long hair cascades below her right elbow and down the right margin of the text, perhaps transformed into a waterfall. Despair and crying are suggested by the figure; perhaps we are to think of the waterfall as her tears. The figure has been variously identified as a personification of Earth (given the presence of other figures on her body) and even as Urizen, in spite of the apparent gender.
On the giant figure's head is a seated figure, probably gowned, facing right and holding (and apparently reading) a book or tablet.
On the giant figure's back are two figures, one standing and facing right. This apparently gowned figure holds a book or tablet in her or his right hand.
The figure seated on the giant's head holds (and apparently reads) a book or tablet. The figure standing on the giant's back also holds a book or tablet.

Just to the right of the figure standing on the giant figure's back is a kneeling figure, with one leg extended back, and the right arm raised at 135 degrees. This figure may be looking up and supplicating or praying.

Standing on the giant figure's upper thigh and leaning against a tree is a figure facing to the right. He wears a broad-brimmed hat and holds and plays a pipe. The presence of what may be sheep further to the right suggests that this is a shepherd.
Standing on the giant figure's upper thigh and leaning against a tree is a figure facing to the right. He wears a broad-brimmed hat and holds and plays a pipe.
A very small figure lies on the giant's calf, facing right. The figure props up its upper body with at least one arm. Given the presence of what may be sheep to the right, this may be a shepherd.

Just to the left of the giant figure's right foot is an embracing couple. The figure most likely to be the female in this group is seated with at least one leg bent at the knee, head facing down, and left arm raised horizontally to embrace her companion.
The man in the embracing couple, left of the giant figure's right foot, kneels on the ground, facing right, with his right arm extended at 45 degrees to touch the woman's left thigh.
On the ground beneath the giant figure's right lower leg, a stag runs or leaps to the right.
The small objects lying on the giant figure's upper leg, right of the small figure under a tree, may be a flock of sheep.
The small objects lying on the giant figure's calf may be a flock of sheep.
The giant figure's hair takes on the character of a waterfall where it cascades into the upper right margin of the text.

The left portion of the design above the text is a forest of at least four leafless trees. Their trunks have anthropomorphic forms. We can also see some of their roots near the left margin; one such root extends along lines 1-9 in the left margin.
A small figure standing on the giant figure's upper thigh leans against a tree with branches but no leaves.
The odd forms on the horizon right of the giant figure suggest hills or more distant mountains. Alternatively, the form at the right margin may be the limbs of a tree.
The ground near the right margin apparently descends over a cliff.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The tailpiece for this final plate is an intertwined pattern of vegetation. It includes two large flower buds (right and left, probably roses), thorny branches from which the buds grow, two smaller flowers (right and left), several vines, and a snake facing to the right with its mouth open and a prominent forked tongue. "FINIS" in white lines is inscribed on the snake's body. There are also two human figures. One stands (and perhaps walks) just below the serpent's head. The figure faces right and has at least one arm raised at 45 degrees. The other figure appears just right of the large flower on the left. This figure is probably standing, facing to the left, and may have at least one arm raised horizontally.

component.illusobjdesc: A small human figure stands (and perhaps walks) on a thorny branch just below the snake's open mouth. The figure faces to the right. At least one arm is raised at 45 degrees.

A small figure stands on a thorny branch to the right of the large flower (probably a rose) on the left side of the design. This figure faces to the left and may have at least one arm raised horizontally.

A snake is intertwined with the vegetation. Its head is on the right; its mouth is open and its forked tongue is prominent. "FINIS" is inscribed on its body near the center of the design. There are a few indications of scales on the snake's body.
A large flower bud, probably a rose, grows from the end of a thorny branch.

A large flower bud, probably a rose, grows from the end of a thorny branch with a loop in it. Another branch extends from the same plant and terminates in a leaf or another flower farther to the right.

Just beneath line 23, three flowers grow at the ends of branches or vines on the same plant. The two flowers on the left, one with spiky petals, appear below the word "flames." The flower on the right appears under the words "heavens, &." There are at least three more flowers in the intertwined vines.

Several vines are intertwined with other vegetation and the snake in the design. Independent of this group are vines, perhaps bearing flowers or leaves, in the right and left bottom corners of the plate.

lg.l: FINIS

component.illusobjdesc: "FINIS" is inscribed in white lines on the body of the snake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curved form, possibly a vine, extends below the last word in line 3. A long, wavy line that may represent a vine dangles from the first letter of the first word ("Stiff"), line 16 of the text. A snake-like line, perhaps representing a vine, descends from the last letter of the last word ("Italy") in the same line.

component.illusobjdesc: A curved form, possibly a vine, extends below the last word in line 3.
A long, wavy line that may represent a vine dangles from the first letter of the first word ("Stiff"), line 16 of the text.
A snake-like line, perhaps representing a vine, descends from the last letter of the last word ("Italy") in line 16 of the text.

lg.l: Over the hills, the vales, the cities, rage the red flames fierce;
The Heavens melted from north to south; and Urizen who sat
Above all heavens in thunders wrap'd, emerg'd his leprous head,
From out his holy shrine, his tears in deluge piteous
Falling into the deep sublime! flag'd with grey-brow'd snows
And thunderous visages, his jealous wings wav'd over the deep;
Weeping in dismal howling woe he dark descended howling
Around the smitten bands, clothed in tears & trembling shudd'ring cold.
His stored snows he poured forth, and his icy magazines
He open'd on the deep. and on the Atlantic sea white shiv'ring.
Leprous his limbs, all over white, and hoary was his visage.
Weeping in dismal howlings before the stern Americans
Hiding the Demon red with clouds & cold mists from the earth;
Till Angels & weak men twelve years should govern o'er the strong;
And then their end should come, when France reciev'd the Demons light.
Stiff shudderings shook the heav'nly thrones! France Spain & Italy,
In terror view'd the bands of Albion, and the ancient Guardians
Fainting upon the elements, smitten with their own plagues
They slow advance to shut the five gates of their law-built heaven
Filled with blasting fancies and with mildews of despair
With fierce disease and lust, unable to stem the fires of Orc;
But the five gates were consum'd, & their bolts and hinges melted
And the fierce flames burnt round the heavens, & round the abodes of
men

FINIS
The word "FINIS" was etched in white line in the tail of the serpent at the bottom of the plate. In some other copies of America , such as Copies O and M, the word has been obscured by color.
